item.title: Four stages of competence in programming
item.description:
I started learning how to code in JavaScript in early 2015 and I had no direction, instruction, or plan. In fact I didn't even know that I wanted to learn JavaScript, I just heard of this "coding" thing on the internet.

This is not how to learn something technical.

Unconscious
item.dc:creator: Todd Levin
item.content:encoded:
I started learning how to code in JavaScript in early 2015 and I had no direction, instruction, or plan. In fact I didn't even know that I wanted to learn JavaScript, I just heard of this "coding" thing on the internet.

This is not how to learn something technical.

Unconscious Competence

If you look at the four stages of competence model, you will start with unconscious incompetence. You don't know a skill and don't recognize that the skill is valuable. You can be oblivious to the entire tech industry and what a programmer actually does. I spent much of my life like this. Ignorance is bliss.

Conscious Incompetence

Once you gain the understanding that you don't know a skill and you think it is very valuable to learn you start the process of learning. You have now entered one of the most frustrating stages, conscious incompetence. You want to learn, you just don't have the skills. You stumble and make mistakes, but this is the basis of learning.

Here is where most people form their base knowledge in a skill. You could scour the online resources such as codeschool, codecademy, treehouse, etc. Here is when finding out what you don't know is important to building a plan. Get involved in discussions on Quora, Stack Overflow, and more to build on your knowledge.

Conscious Competence

Conscious competence is the stage that people strive for. A point that with conscious thought you have knowledge of a skill. I think of it as having enough knowledge to be 'dangerous'. You can function professionally as a programmer at this stage, but you lack a certain level of 'optimization'.

Unconscious Competence

Unconscious competence is the final stage of mastery in a skill. You can code without significant concentration and thought. This is akin to 'autopilot' with coding. It is more often achieved more through practice and persistence than any one learning resource.

In software engineering mastery of individual skills may be possible, but as a whole it is a constant learning process. That is why I love it.

item.title: Overcoming Imposter Syndrome
item.description: I believe that what my single greatest hurdle in becoming a software engineer is accepting the idea that I can be successful at it. I started learning to code earlier this year and it was imposing to say the least. The diverse technologies available to learn combined with how in-depth
item.dc:creator: Todd Levin
item.content:encoded:
I believe that what my single greatest hurdle in becoming a software engineer is accepting the idea that I can be successful at it. I started learning to code earlier this year and it was imposing to say the least. The diverse technologies available to learn combined with how in-depth and complicated these programming languages appeared to be made starting difficult.

So I did what most people do when they don’t know where to start, I asked random people on the internet. I found the site Quora which was a wealth of information from people in the industry. Impressive credentials, with complex, intelligent answers built up my feelings of inadequacy.

I started learning JavaScript with the intention of interviewing with Hack Reactor. I set upon learning with a passion and improved my skills rapidly. I began solving more and more complex problems and eventually got accepted by Hack Reactor despite how highly selective they are. Throughout this process I thought I had no chance and wasn’t good enough.

I found out there is a concept that is prevalent in software engineering called the ‘Imposter Syndrome’ which is a belief, despite evidence to the contrary, that success is the result of luck, timing, or the work of others. The idea that you are a fraud amongst ‘real’ software engineers.

The work I have done on the prerequisite studies for Hack Reactor and my interactions with fellow classmates made me aware that the feeling of inadequacy was fairly common. I continue to have success that I attribute to persistence and a stubborn desire to solve the problem. One day I hope I can acknowledge that my success is the result of technical skill.
